baseline_groups.claim_summary: The 1927 Mississippi flood caused a persistent decline in Black population share and Black population in affected Southern US counties, consistent with flood-induced out-migration of Black agricultural workers.
baseline_groups.notes: Primary baseline is Table 2 Column 1 (run_0001): lnfrac_black ~ f_int_YEAR panel DiD with county FE, state-year FE, geography controls, lagged DVs, clustered at fips, weighted by county_w. Focal coefficient is f_int_1930. Additional baselines include New Deal controls variant (run_0002), alternative outcome lnpopulation_black (runs 0007-0008), and Table 1 cross-sectional long-difference baselines (runs 0025-0030) which use flood_intensity as treatment in a cross-sectional design. The failed baselines for lnpopulation (run_0013) and lnfracfarms_nonwhite (runs 0019-0020) are due to matrix singularity.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The 1927 Mississippi flood caused increases in agricultural capital intensity (farm size, equipment value, tractors) in affected Southern US counties, consistent with labor-scarcity-induced mechanization.
baseline_groups.notes: Multiple baseline outcomes: lnvalue_equipment (runs 0036-0037, only _nd variant succeeds), lntractors (runs 0041-0042), lnmules_horses (runs 0046-0047, only base succeeds), lnavfarmsize (runs 0031-0032, both fail), lnfarmland_a (runs 0051-0052, both fail), lnlandbuildingvalue(f) (runs 0053-0056, all fail). High failure rate (14 of 26 specs) due to matrix singularity in sparse agricultural census panel. The lntractors outcome shows the strongest positive result (coef=0.51, p=0.001). Equipment value baseline (_nd variant, run_0037) has near-zero coefficient (coef=-0.0006, p=0.994), suggesting this outcome is not robust.

global_notes: Surface defined two baseline groups: G1 (labor/population outcomes) and G2 (capital/agricultural outcomes). No changes to baseline-group assignments from the surface. 56 specifications total (30 G1, 26 G2). 31 succeeded and 25 failed, all due to matrix singularity from collinear time-interacted controls. G1 results are strongly robust with consistent negative coefficients for Black population share. G2 results are mixed: tractor adoption shows strong positive effects, but equipment value and other capital measures show weak or null effects. The rc/inference/hc1_* specs (runs 0006, 0012, 0018, 0024) are effectively inference variants placed in specification_results.csv rather than inference_results.csv; they duplicate the coefficient from their corresponding baseline but with HC1 robust SEs. The Table 1 cross-sectional baselines (runs 0025-0030) use a different design (long difference, cross-sectional) from the main panel specifications.
